Docs.summary: Represents a selection control with a drop-down list that can be shown or hidden by clicking the arrow on the control.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The ComboBox allows the user to select an item from a drop-down list or optionally to enter new text in the text box of the control. ComboBox is an , which means it can contain a collection of objects of any type (such as string, image, or panel). For more information, see the class. The and properties specify how the ComboBox behaves when the user does one of the following: - Enters a string to select an item in the ComboBox. - Enters a string that does not correspond to an item in the ComboBox. - Selects part of the string that is in the text box. - Copies or pastes a value into the text box. The following table describes the actions the user can and cannot take, depending on the values of and . || is `true`| is `false`| |-|--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------| | is `true`|- Cannot select an item in the ComboBox by entering a string.
- Cannot enter a string that does not correspond to an item in the ComboBox.
- Can select part of the string in the ComboBox text box.
- Can copy the string in the ComboBox text box, but cannot paste a string into the ComboBox text box.|- Can select an item in the ComboBox by entering a string.
- Can enter a string that does not correspond to an item in the ComboBox.
- Can select part of the string in the ComboBox text box.
- Can copy or paste the string in the ComboBox text box.| | is `false`|- Can select an item in the ComboBox by entering a string.
- Cannot enter a string that does not correspond to an item in the ComboBox.
- Cannot select part of the string in the ComboBox.
- Cannot copy or paste the string in the ComboBox.|- Can select an item in the ComboBox by entering a string.
- Cannot enter a string that does not correspond to an item in the ComboBox.
- Cannot select part of the string in the ComboBox.
- Cannot copy or paste the string in the ComboBox.| The property has an effect only if is `true`. The ComboBox is an , so it can display content other than simple strings. For example, you can create a ComboBox that contains a list of images. When you have content other than strings in the ComboBox, a nonsensical string might appear in the ComboBox when the drop-down list is hidden. To display a string in the ComboBox when it contains non-string items, use the or attached property. ## Customizing the ComboBox Control To apply the same property settings to multiple ComboBox controls, use the property. You can modify the default to give the control a unique appearance. For more information about creating a , see [Customizing the Appearance of an Existing Control by Creating a ControlTemplate](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md). To see the parts and states that are specific to the ComboBox, see [ComboBox Styles and Templates](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md). Dependency properties for this control might be set by the controlâ€™s default style. If a property is set by a default style, the property might change from its default value when the control appears in the application. The default style is determined by which desktop theme is used when the application is running. For more information, see [Default WPF Themes](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=158252). > [!NOTE] > Setting a visual property will only have an effect if that property is both present in ComboBox control's default template and is set by using a . You can find a list of visual properties in the "Changing the Visual Structure of a Control" section in [Customizing the Appearance of an Existing Control by Creating a ControlTemplate](../Topic/Customizing%20the%20Appearance%20of%20an%20Existing%20Control%20by%20Creating%20a%20ControlTemplate.md). ## Examples The following example creates a ComboBox. The example populates the ComboBox by binding the property to a collection object of type `VacationSpots`. The example also creates a that displays the selected item of the ComboBox. [!code-xml[ComboBoxItems#ComboBoxClass](~/add/codesnippet/xaml/ComboBox_Index/Window1.xaml#comboboxclass)] The following example defines the collection object that the ComboBox in the preceding example binds to. [!code-cs[ComboBoxItems#Data](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/ComboBox_Index/Window1.xaml.cs#data)] [!code-vb[ComboBoxItems#Data](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/ComboBox_Index/Window1.xaml.vb#data)]

Docs.summary: Creates or identifies the element used to display the specified item.
Docs.returns: The element used to display the specified item.

Docs.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether a combo box supports scrolling.
Docs.value: if the supports scrolling; otherwise, . The default is .

remarks.format: ## Remarks If the control has a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ScrollViewer> in its style and has a custom keyboard scrolling behavior, <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ListBox.HandlesScrolling%2A> should return `true`.

Docs.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether the has focus.
Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the drop-down for a combo box is currently open.
Docs.value: if the drop-down is open; otherwise, . The default is .

remarks.format: ## Remarks ## Dependency Property Information ||| |-|-| |Identifier field|| |Metadata properties set to `true`|| ## Examples The following example shows how to use the IsDropDownOpen property to create a combo box with the drop down control opened when the combo box is initiated. [!code-xml[ComboBoxStyles#4](~/add/codesnippet/xaml/ComboBoxStyles/app.xaml#4)]

Docs.summary: Identifies the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ComboBox.IsDropDownOpen%2A> dependency property.
Gets or sets a value that enables or disables editing of the text in text box of the .
Docs.value: if the can be edited; otherwise . The default is .

remarks.format:
## Remarks The IsEditable and properties specify how the behaves when the user does one of the following: - Enters a string to select an item in the . - Enters a string that does not correspond to an item in the . - Selects part of the string that is in the text box. - Copies or pastes a value into the text box. The following table describes the actions the user can and cannot take, depending on the values of IsEditable and . || is `true`| is `false`| |-|--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------| |IsEditable is `true`|- Cannot select an item in the by entering a string.
- Cannot enter a string that does not correspond to an item in the .
- Can select part of the string in the text box.
- Can copy the string in the text box, but cannot paste a string into the text box.|- Can select an item in the by entering a string.
- Can enter a string that does not correspond to an item in the .
- Can select part of the string in the text box.
- Can copy or paste the string in the text box.| |IsEditable is `false`|- Can select an item in the by entering a string.
- Cannot enter a string that does not correspond to an item in the .
- Cannot select part of the string in the .
- Cannot copy or paste the string in the .|- Can select an item in the by entering a string.
- Cannot enter a string that does not correspond to an item in the .
- Cannot select part of the string in the .
- Cannot copy or paste the string in the .| When IsEditable is equal to `false`, the uses a to display the currently selected item; when IsEditable is equal to `true`, a is used for this purpose instead. Note that a only displays plain text, and that a may include non-plain text content, such as images. ## Dependency Property Information ||| |-|-| |Identifier field|| |Metadata properties set to `true`|None| ## Examples The following examples create controls that contain images as items instead of text. If the IsEditable property is set to `true`, the displays the value returned by the image's method. To avoid a with unexpected text, use the and properties to assign text to be displayed. [!code-xml[ComboBoxProps_snip#1](~/add/codesnippet/xaml/comboboxsimple/pane1.xaml#1)] [!code-xml[ComboBoxProps_snip#2](~/add/codesnippet/xaml/comboboxsimple/pane1.xaml#2)] Another solution is to use the property. The drop-down control of the will not display the images but will display the text you assigned. The following example shows how to use . [!code-xml[ComboBoxProps_snip#3](~/add/codesnippet/xaml/comboboxsimple/pane1.xaml#3)]

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value that enables selection-only mode, in which the contents of the combo box are selectable but not editable.
Docs.value: if the is read-only; otherwise, . The default is .

remarks.format:
## Remarks The and IsReadOnly properties specify how the behaves when the user does one of the following: - Enters a string to select an item in the . - Enters a string that does not correspond to an item in the . - Selects part of the string that is in the text box. - Copies or pastes a value into the text box. The following table describes the actions the user can and cannot take, depending on the values of and IsReadOnly. ||IsReadOnly is `true`|IsReadOnly is `false`| |-|--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------| | is `true`|- Cannot select an item in the by entering a string.
- Cannot enter a string that does not correspond to an item in the .
- Can select part of the string in the text box.
- Can copy the string in the text box, but cannot paste a string into the text box.|- Can select an item in the by entering a string.
- Can enter a string that does not correspond to an item in the .
- Can select part of the string in the text box.
- Can copy or paste the string in the text box.| | is `false`|- Can select an item in the by entering a string.
- Cannot enter a string that does not correspond to an item in the .
- Cannot select part of the string in the .
- Cannot copy or paste the string in the .|- Can select an item in the by entering a string.
- Cannot enter a string that does not correspond to an item in the .
- Cannot select part of the string in the .
- Cannot copy or paste the string in the .| When is equal to `false`, the uses a to display the currently selected item; when is equal to `true`, a is used for this purpose instead. Note that a only displays plain text, and that a may include non-plain text content, such as images. ## Dependency Property Information ||| |-|-| |Identifier field|| |Metadata properties set to `true`|| ## Examples The following example shows a with an editable . The IsReadOnly property is set to `true`, so the user cannot enter text into the . [!code-xml[ComboBoxItems#1](~/add/codesnippet/xaml/ComboBox_Index/Window1.xaml#1)]

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static initonly class System.Windows.DependencyProperty IsReadOnlyProperty

Docs.summary: Identifies the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ComboBox.IsReadOnly%2A> dependency property.
Gets whether the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ComboBox.SelectionBoxItem%2A> is highlighted.

remarks.format: ## Remarks This property is a dependency property. However, the dependency property identifier field for IsSelectionBoxHighlighted is not public. Therefore, you cannot use the backing dependency property for property system operations that require the dependency property identifier, such as calls to <xref:System.Windows.DependencyObject.GetValue%2A>. However, you can still use IsSelectionBoxHighlighted as a property trigger.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the maximum height for a combo box drop-down.
Docs.value: A double that represents the height that is retrieved or the height to set. The default value as defined to the property system is a calculated value based on taking a one-third fraction of the system max screen height parameters, but this default is potentially overridden by various control templates.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Auto sizing is not the default, and will result in the drop down size potentially exceeding the available size in the parent element. This is not typically desirable. ## Dependency Property Information ||| |-|-| |Identifier field|| |Metadata properties set to `true`|None| ## XAML Attribute Usage ``` - or â€“ - or - ``` ## XAML Values *double* String representation of a value. This is interpreted as a [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_dipixel](~/add/includes/tlasharptla-dipixel-md.md)] measurement. Strings need not explicitly include decimal points. For instance a value of `1` is acceptable. The same range restrictions as mentioned in the Property Value section apply. *qualifiedDouble* A *double* value as described above, followed by one of the following unit declaration strings: `px`, `in`, `cm`, `pt`. `px` (default) is [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_dipixel#plural](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md)] `in` is inches; 1in==96px `cm` is centimeters; 1cm==(96/2.54) px `pt` is points; 1pt==(96/72) px `Auto` Enables autosizing behavior. See Remarks. ## Examples The following example shows how to use the MaxDropDownHeight property to specify the height of the control's drop-down. [!code-xml[ComboBoxStyles#5](~/add/codesnippet/xaml/ComboBoxStyles/app.xaml#5)]

To get the selected item of the outside of the , use the property instead of this property. ## XAML Attribute Usage ``` ``` ## Dependency Property Information ||| |-|-| |Identifier field|| |Metadata properties set to `true`|None| ## Examples The following example binds the property of a to the SelectionBoxItem property. MemberSignature.Value: .field public static initonly class System.Windows.DependencyProperty SelectionBoxItemTemplateProperty

Docs.summary: Identifies the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ComboBox.SelectionBoxItemTemplate%2A> dependency property.
Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the keeps the user's input or replaces the input with a matching item.
Docs.value: if the keeps the user's input; if the replaces the input with a matching item The registered default is . For more information about what can influence the value, see [Dependency Property Value Precedence](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).

remarks.format: ## Remarks By default, when the user types a string into the that matches one of its items, the item is selected and the text that the user typed is replaced. This can cause the text that the user entered to change case. If the ShouldPreserveUserEnteredPrefix property is set to `true`, the selects the matching item, but preserves the text that the user entered. For example, suppose that a contains the string, "Hello" (with a capital H) and the user enters "hello" (with a lowercase h). If ShouldPreserveUserEnteredPrefix is `false`, the selects the matching item, "Hello," in its collection and populates its text box with that string. If ShouldPreserveUserEnteredPrefix is `true`, "Hello" is selected from the collection, but the text box says "hello." ## Dependency Property Information ||| |-|-| |Identifier field|| |Metadata properties set to `true`|None|

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static initonly class System.Windows.DependencyProperty ShouldPreserveUserEnteredPrefixProperty

Docs.summary: Identifies the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ComboBox.ShouldPreserveUserEnteredPrefix%2A> dependency property.
Gets or sets whether a that is open and displays a drop-down control will remain open when a user clicks the .
Docs.value: to keep the drop-down control open when the user clicks on the text area to start editing; otherwise, . The default is .

Gets or sets the text of the currently selected item.
Docs.value: The string of the currently selected item. The default is an empty string ("").

remarks.format: ## Remarks When the property is `true`, setting this property places initial text entered in the text box. When is `false`, setting this value has no effect. ## Dependency Property Information ||| |-|-| |Identifier field|| |Metadata properties set to `true`|, | ## Examples This example shows how the Text property can be used to set text into the before the user makes a selection. [!code-xml[ComboBoxItems#1](~/add/codesnippet/xaml/ComboBox_Index/Window1.xaml#1)]
